thread.title: Gina Rineheart among guests at Malcolm Turnbull luncheon
thread.title_full: Gina Rineheart among guests at Malcolm Turnbull luncheon | Daily Mail Online

author: Daniel Peters For Daily Mail Australia
title: Gina Rineheart among guests at Malcolm Turnbull luncheon
text:
Billionaire mining magnate Gina Rinehart and a group of Australia's business and political elite have joined Malcolm Turnbull in welcoming Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin 'Bibi' Netanyahu to the country.
An exclusive business luncheon, hosted by Mr Turnbull at the Sydney Convention Centre on Wednesday, saw current and former politicians, community figures and industry leaders file past tough security checks at the entrance.
Property developer Harry Triguboff, founder and director of Meriton and one of the richest people in Australia, was photographed shaking hands with former Prime Minister John Howard outside the centre.
Mr Netanyahu, who is the first serving Israeli Prime Minister to visit Australian, is on the first of a historic four-day tour of the country and has already taken part in a joint press conference with Mr Turnbull.
Gina Rinehart arrives at the Sydney Convention Centre on Wednesday for an Israeli-Australian business luncheon
The billionaire mining magnate and some of Australia's business elite joined Malcolm Turnbull in welcoming Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin 'Bibi' Netanyahu to the country
Billionaire residential property developer Harry Triguboff (left) shakes hand with former Liberal Prime Minister John Howard
Mr Turnbull and Opposition Leader Bill Shorten both spoke at the business luncheon
Noticeably absent from the influential crowd was billionaire casino mogul James Packer, a close friend of Mr Netanyahu's who is facing significant scrutiny in Israel over allegations he gifted expensive presents to the leader's son Yair.
Local media also reports that Packer's lawyer asked Mr Netanyahu's Interior Minister whether it was possible for the Crown Casino owner citizenship in Israel.
Also present at the lunch was NSW Police Commissioner Andrew Scipione, who recently announced his early retirement from the top job, Opposition Leader Bill Shorten and Scott Morrison, Minister for Social Services.
Mr Turnbull praised the state of Israel as a 'modern miracle' and described it as the original start-up nation during the Israel-Australia business luncheon.
He said Jewish Australians played an important part in the development of Australia.
Mr Howard (left) and Israeli PM Benjamin 'Bibi' Netanyahu engage in conversation at a table
Ms Rinehart, chairman of Hancock Prospecting, listened to instructions given to her by a police officer as she arrived at the luncheon
Mr Triguboff, the founder and managing director of hotel chain Meriton, waits for his personal items after going through a security check
Also present at the luncheon was NSW Police Commissioner Andrew Scipione (left) and Scott Morrison (right), Minister for Social Services
'Israel (is) the original start-up nation,' he said while praising the country's innovation drive.
Mr Turnbull received a round of applause from the audience after denouncing a recent UN resolution condemning settlements and the boycott, divestment and sanctions movement, the latter of which he said Australia 'deplores'.
Earlier on Wednesday, Mr Turnbull and Mr Netanyahu spoke extensively about national security matters, including cyber security during bilateral talks.
Mr Netanyahu thanked Mr Turnbull for the warm welcome as the first sitting Israeli prime minister to officially visit Australia.
'The first thing I should say is G'day mate,' Mr Netanyahu told reporters.
Mr Netanyahu invited Mr Turnbull to visit Israel in late October to commemorate 100 years since the Battle of Beersheba.
Australia's 4th Light Horse Brigade were involved in a famous mounted charge.
'You come as a great friend of our people and our civilisation,' Mr Netanyahu said.
Mr Netanyahu hit back at calls by former prime ministers Kevin Rudd and Bob Hawke for Labor to recognise a Palestinian state.
'What kind of state will it be that they are advocating? A state that calls for Israel's destruction?
'A state whose territory will be used immediately for radical Islam?'
Mr Netanyahu is the first Israeli prime minister to set foot on Australian soil
Mr Netanyahu takes a drink during the luncheon. Mr Turnbull told the crowd that Israel was 'the original start-up nation'
Mr Turnbull said Australia has always supported a two-state solution, where the Israeli and Palestinian people can live side-by-side.
'It needs to be resolved by direct negotiations between the parties and we certainly encourage that,' he said.
'We do not support one-sided resolutions which condemn or criticise Israel.'
Mr Netanyahu declined to give detailed comment on reports he is being investigated for allegedly accepting gifts from Australian billionaire James Packer.
'I think nothing will come of it because there is nothing there, except friendship, which is a good thing.'
Wearing matching blue suits and ties, Malcolm Turnbull (left) greeted Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu (right) in Sydney on Wednesday for his four-day tour of Australia
The prime ministers (pictured) spoke extensively about national security matters, including cyber security, during bilateral talks in Sydney earlier on Wednesday
Mr Netanyahu invited Mr Turnbull to visit Israel in late October to commemorate 100 years since the Battle of Beersheba
Mr Netanyahu said he did not want to incorporate two million Palestinians as citizens of Israel nor did he want them to be the subject of Israel.
'I want them to have all the freedoms to govern themselves but none of the powers to threaten us,' he said.
'Let them govern themselves, but not have the the military and physical power to threaten the state of Israel.'
He said the settlements issue was 'way overblown'.
'The core of the conflict between us and the Palestinians is their persistent refusal to recognise a Jewish state in any boundary,' he said.
'And once they recognise a Jewish state, once they recognise the permanence of Israel and the right of Israel to be there as the nation state of the Jewish people, in our ancestral homeland ... everything else will fall in place.'
Reactions to Mr Natanyahu's visit will be mixed, with political and business leaders welcoming him with open arms amid protests by pro-Palestinian groups
Mr Netanyahu (second from left) and his wife Sara (second from right) walk with Mr Turnbull (left) and his wife Lucy (right) during their visit
